PARTNERSHIPS WITH NONGOVERNMENT ORGANIZATIONS 
 

Rationale 

A. 
 
The Project will enter into partnership arrangements with nongovernment organizations 
1. 
(NGOs)  to  assist  subsistence  and  semi-commercial  stakeholders—farmers,  traders,  and 
processors—who  are  not  eligible  for  commercial  agriculture  alliance  (CAA)  membership  but 
have  potential  to  develop  such  eligibility  if  they  receive  support  to  overcome  their  difficulties. 
These  stakeholders  are  generally  engaged  in  subsistence  activities  or  some  small-scale 
commercial undertakings. With support from the partner NGOs, stakeholders who are producing 
only enough for subsistence are expected to be able to generate additional income and take up 
commercial  activities,  while  those  already  engaged  in  commercial  activities  beyond  their 
subsistence  needs  will  be  able  to  increase  their  turnover  and  become  eligible  for  CAA 
membership.  
 
2. 
The  project  inputs  that  the  partner  NGOs  will  deliver  to  such  stakeholders  include 
community  mobilization,  social  inclusion  activities,  farmer  group  formation  and  strengthening, 
and  monitoring  and  evaluation.  The  types  of  services  to  be  provided  by  the  NGOs  will  be 
specified in the partnership agreement reflecting the needs of the target groups, capacity of the 
partner NGO, and commercial agricultural focus of the Project. 
 
3. 
The partner NGOs are preferably based in the Eastern Development Region (EDR) and 
registered  in  one  of  the  districts  in  the  project  area.  They  should  preferably  have  experience 
working in more than one district. Any exception to this must be justified and documented. 

 

4. 
The project management unit (PMU) will enter directly into partnership agreements with 
several NGOs. The actual number will depend on the capacity of the NGO and ability of PMU 
staff  to  provide  effective  and  meaningful  time  inputs  to  support  the  partner  NGOs.  Depending 
upon the existing skill mix of partner NGOs and type of support needed in the district, the PMU 
may  engage  more  than  one  partner  NGO  in  the  same  district  but  in  separate  locations  or  on 
different  tasks.  This  will  increase  collaboration  and  mutual  learning  together  with  a  feeling  of 
competitiveness for quality between partner NGOs. 
 
5. 
The partner NGOs will engage local NGOs that are working closely with the communities 
in the project area for particular services and functions. The partner NGOs will provide training 
and  coaching  to  their  local  counterparts  as  required  to  enhance  performance  quality.  The 
application  submitted  by  the  NGO  for  partnership  with  the  PMU  will  give  the  names  and 
description of the counterpart local NGOs they work with and the selection criteria they applied. 
The  capacity-building  activities  of  local  NGOs  will  contribute  to  sustainability,  decentralization, 
and local acceptance/ownership of activities supported by the Project. 
 
6. 
As agricultural marketing is a new area of activity, capacity building of partner NGOs and 
through them of local NGOs is required to enable them to effectively fulfill their roles. When local 
NGOs  are  strengthened  they  will  be  able  to  provide  ongoing  services  to  the  disadvantaged, 
poor,  and  women;  and  produce  lasting  improvements  in  their  living  conditions.  Efforts  will  be 
made to develop decentralized NGO-based support services.  
 
7. 
To make services to these stakeholders relevant and effective, different services will be 
required at different stages during the development life-cycle of local organizations and groups. 
The PMU will regularly assess and plan jointly with the partner NGOs and farmer organization 
leaders for more advanced capacity development. Proposed services will also take into account

the  target  beneficiary’s  opportunities  and  constraints  (season,  time,  duration,  frequency,  and 
time gaps).

SELECTION PROCESS AND CRITERIA FOR SERVICE PROVIDERS 

 
1. 
The  project  management  unit  (PMU)  will  contract  selected  service  providers  to  deliver 
specialized services including advanced training to commercial stakeholders, district staff of the 
Department  of  Agriculture,  and  partner  nongovernment  organizations  (NGOs).  The  specific 
areas  include  product  processing,  use  of  processing  equipment,  quality  assurance  systems,

teaching  or  research  institutes,  industry,  Agro  Enterprise  Center,  chambers  of  commerce, 
specialized NGOs, and others.

for the tasks and objectives to be achieved. The contract document will specify the tasks, work 
plan, reporting requirements, costs, and provision of supervision and guidance by the PMU.

PROJECT JUSTIFICATION AND ECONOMIC ANALYSIS 

Project Justification and Beneficiaries 

 
1. 
The  Project  is  designed  to  efficiently  deliver  development  to  the  poor  and  socially 
excluded  through  equitable  and  sustainable  commercialization  of  agriculture.  The  social 
inclusion  component  will  promote  the  participation  of  all  stakeholders  including  the  poor, 
disadvantaged, and women in commercial agriculture; and help them receive fair benefits from 
such participation. In this way, the Project will greatly contribute to restoring peace and stability 
in  Nepal.  The  Project  will  directly  generate  employment  opportunities  to  poor  and  marginal 
farmers  and  landless  people  by  promoting  high-value  crop  (HVC)  production  and  marketing, 
transporting agriculture products from the field to storage and processing centers, and assisting 
small-scale community-based market infrastructure development. The Project will also help fully 
commercial  stakeholders  to  become  more  efficient  and  successful,  at  the  same  time  ensuring 
they adopt socially inclusive behavior and activities that help the less advantaged. Investments 
by  the  private  sector,  a  crucial  partner  for  commercial  agriculture  development,  will  directly 
generate  job  opportunities  for  poor  farmers  and  enhance  the  value  addition  of  agriculture 
products. 
 
A. 
 
The growth of the rural economy is essential to poverty reduction and national economic 
2. 
growth.  Most  of  the  poor  in  the  country  live  in  rural  areas  and  derive  their  livelihoods  from 
agriculture. Acceleration of agricultural growth will not be possible if strategies continue to focus 
mainly on production. For the agriculture sector to grow and generate large benefits for the rural 
economy  and  the  poor,  agriculture  must  be  reoriented  to  commercial  production,  processing, 
and  marketing.  The  growth  of  commercial  agricultural  activities  will  increase  employment  and 
income in rural areas; stimulate farm and nonfarm activities such as agroprocessing, marketing, 
and  business  services;  establish  value-chain 
traders,  and 
agroprocessors; and generate value addition of products. 
 
3. 
The  main  project  beneficiaries  will  be  farmers  (including  subsistence  and  women 
farmers)  growing  or  interested  in  growing  HVCs  such  as  vegetables,  fruits,  and  spices;  and 
entrepreneurs located in the identified high potential areas of the Eastern Development Region 
(EDR). Since women constitute the majority of the agricultural labor force, the Project identifies 
means to facilitate their full participation and ensure commensurate benefits to them. The EDR 
was  identified  because  of  its  agroclimatic  suitability  for  HVC  production,  and  the  availability  of 
irrigation and road infrastructure created by previous government and external investments. The 
project  design  incorporates  lessons  from  past  projects  and  builds  synergy  with  past  and 
upcoming investments in the sector indicated in the Tenth Five-Year Plan. 
 
The Project’s target groups are subsistence, semi-commercial, and commercial farmers, 
4. 
processors,  and  traders.  Subsistence  stakeholders  include  landless,  smallholder  farmers  and 
small  processors  and  traders,  who  produce  only  enough  for  their  subsistence  and  have  no 
meaningful  surplus  for  sale.  Semi-commercial  stakeholders  are  farmers,  traders,  processors, 
and  retailers  whose  marketable  output  is  periodic,  seasonal,  or  uncertain.  Commercial 
stakeholders  comprise  groups,  alliances,  cooperatives,  and  companies  who  as  their  main 
occupation produce, process, and engage in trade for the purpose of selling agriculture products 
on  a  regular  basis.  The  subsistence  and  semi-commercial  stakeholders  will  benefit  from 
subprojects  relating  to  marketing  infrastructure  such  as  farm-to-market  roads,  river  crossings, 
collection and storage facilities, and market-related technology training for which up to 75% of 
the  cost  will  be  financed  by  the  commercial  agriculture  fund  (CAF).  Commercial  stakeholders 

linkages  among 

farmers,

will  benefit  from  subprojects  to  strengthen  and  shorten  supply-chain  linkages;  disseminate 
product storage, processing, and packaging technology; and provide support to address policy 
and regulatory constraints. The CAF will finance up to 50% of the cost of subprojects proposed 
by  commercial  stakeholders.  Subprojects  initiated  by  commercial  stakeholders  should  also 
benefit  subsistence  and  semi-commercial  farmers,  traders,  processors,  and  retailers.  Thus, 
subsistence and semi-commercial stakeholders will be the major beneficiaries of the CAF. 
 
B. 
 

Indicative Subproject Analysis 

1. 

Approach and Methodology 

 
5. 
The  Project  is  designed  to  stimulate  commercial  activities  in  the  agriculture  sector 
ranging from preproduction support through commercial production to postproduction handling, 
processing,  transport,  storage,  and  marketing.  All  the  investments  will  be  demand  driven  and 
identified during implementation. As a result, the likely mix of the scale and type of interventions 
and the overall project benefits cannot be accurately ascertained. Thus, undertaking a full-scale 
benefit-cost  analysis  is  not  practical.  Instead,  representative  subprojects  that  could  be 
implemented by the Project were analyzed. 
 
In  accordance  with  ADB’s  Guidelines  for  the  Economic  Analysis  of  Projects,1  the 
6. 
representative subproject analysis is based on the investment budget model with a breakdown 
of revenue and cost by investment outputs and inputs, and projected cash inflows and outflows 
over  15  years,  priced  at  constant  2006  prices.  Sensitivity  analyses  of  the  risk  of  a  shorter 
economic  life  expectancy  were  conducted.  All  revenues,  benefits,  and  costs  are  incremental, 
and expressed in 2006 prices in Nepalese rupees. An average mid-2006 official exchange rate 
of  NRs73.74  per  $1.00  is  applied  to  convert  foreign  exchange  costs  to  their  local  currency 
equivalent. The analytical framework includes the following: 

(i) 

(ii) 

(iii) 

(iv) 

(v) 

All  prices,  benefits,  and  costs  are  adjusted  to  2006  constant  values  using  (a)  a 
gross domestic product deflator for all local currency benefits and costs, and (b) 
the G-5 manufacturer’s unit value index for all foreign exchange.  
A discount rate of 12 % is used to calculate the net present value and as a cut-off 
point for the economic internal rate of return. 
The project benefits and costs in financial prices are adjusted to economic prices 
by deducting taxes and duties, and by applying item-specific conversion factors 
to nontraded local currency costs. 
Specific  conversion  factors  for  various  project  inputs  and  outputs  are  based  on 
estimated  shares  of  foreign  exchange  and  labor.  Some  key  conversion  factors 
include 0.66 for vehicles, 0.70 for local manufactures and extracted materials, 0.7 
for  community-based  infrastructure  maintenance,  and  0.93  as  the  standard 
conversion factors. 
A shadow rural wage rate of 0.87 is estimated and applied to unskilled labor to 
reflect un- and underemployment in the project area.

8. 
Developing  community-based  market  infrastructure  will  enable  the  Project  to  address 
one of the major constraints in marketing—linking farmers to markets. Following the awareness-
building activities of the Project, farmer communities will identify subprojects. Subprojects will be 
approved  when  the  farmer  communities  can  demonstrate  (i)  community  need,  (ii)  that  the 
investment can be managed and maintained by the community, (iii) that the investment will add 
value to marketing activities, (iv) that benefits will apply equitably to the community or group and 
not to individuals, and (v) that the upstream and downstream value-chain linkages have positive 
benefits for others, e.g., unemployed. 
 
The establishment of small collection centers is expected to generate employment and 
9. 
revenue in rural areas. Benefits will also accrue to farmers and traders, as they are expected to 
realize  (i)  significant  savings  in  time  and  cost  in  the  transport  and  marketing  of  agricultural 
products; and (ii) reduction in losses in product quality due to establishment of these centers at 
strategic locations that are easily accessible to producers and buyers. Upgrading farm-to-market 
roads  will  encourage  development  of  idle  lands  for  agricultural  production,  resulting  in 
incremental production/revenues  for  farmers  and  increased  agricultural  products  traded  locally 
by  intermediaries.  Investments  in  technology  enhancement  subprojects  (i.e.,  postharvest 
packaging,  storage  facilities,  feed  production,  and  extension)  are  expected  to  result  in  (i) 
reduction  in  costs  due  to  postharvest  losses  among  farmers  and  traders;  (ii)  lower  production 
costs for feed processors, subsequently lower feed price for farmers; and (iii) incremental farm 
production.  Investments  in  marketing  subprojects  are  envisaged  to  benefit  both  farmers  and 
traders.  Better  market  information  will  allow  them  to  sell  products  at  competitive  prices  and  in 
markets where they may be able to effectively compete. Capacity development of farmers and 
processors is expected to improve productivity.

Capacity Strengthening for Appraising Subprojects 

Sensitivity  analysis  was  conducted  to  test  the  significance  of  the  benefit  and  cost 
10. 
assumptions.  The  representative  market  infrastructure  subprojects  remain  robust  to  impact 
changes  caused  by  (i)  capital  cost  increased  by  20%,  (ii)  operation  and  maintenance  cost 
increased  by  20%,  (iii)  benefits  reduced  by  20%,  and  (iv)  combination  of  the  three  adverse 
effects.  Most  technology  and  marketing  related  subprojects  are  also  found  to  be  robust  with 
impact changes caused by (i) demonstration cost increased by 20%, (ii) training cost increased 
by 20%, and (iii) revenue decreased by 20%. The tests indicate that viability is more sensitive to 
a reduction in benefits than to an increase in costs. 
 
C. 
 
11. 
Careful  review  and  appraisal  of  subproject  proposals  are  important.  Appendix  4 
discusses in detail the criteria for subproject review procedures and selection. A district review 
committee with representation of an outside technical expert will undertake the initial review and 
selection  of  the  CAF  proposals  submitted  by  CAA  members  within  the  district.  The  district 
review  committee  may  also  seek  technical  advice  from  external  parties  to  facilitate  the  initial 
screening of CAF applications. 
 
12. 
Additional provisions under component 4 of the Project will enhance CAA staff capacity 
to  appraise  subprojects.  CAA  district  branch  staff  and  district  review  committee  members  will 
specifically  be  strengthened  on  investment  analysis,  project  appraisal,  and  management  of 
meetings  to  help  them  meet  their  responsibilities  for  CAA  activities  and  review  proposals  for 
CAF funding. To ensure efficient implementation of the subprojects, a monitoring and evaluation 
officer will be fielded at each CAA district branch. 
 
D. 
 
13. 
The  cumulative  impact  of  the  Project  on  the  economy  as  a  whole  will  be  significant 
through direct increases in production, increases in value added, and employment generation. 
Increased demand for agricultural produce for processing and urban sales will result in higher 
farmer prices; greater quantities of produce marketed; and a multiplier effect generated through 
greater demands for on-farm labor, transport, storage, and handling. Disadvantaged segments 
of the community will benefit from the increased demand for labor and farm produce. 
 
14. 
Income.  A  multiplier  effect  on  the  incomes  of  beneficiaries  in  the  project  area  is 
expected. Direct positive income effects will accrue to rural households undertaking commercial 
agriculture activities. Indirect benefits will affect suppliers of input goods and services. A large 
benefit  in  income  generation  will  flow  to  a  wide  range  of  farmers  who  may  be  suppliers  of 
agroprocessing businesses or directly participate as commercial farmers. 
 
Employment.  The  rural  labor  force  will  benefit  directly  through  increased  employment 
15. 
opportunities.  Employment  effects  are  expected  to  be  significant,  particularly  for  women.  The 
Project  will  assist  marginal  farmers  and  the  landless  to  organize  into  groups;  strengthen  their 
capacity for improved production of HVCs, off-season vegetables, and fruits with high demand; 
and to graduate to commercial farming. The Project will follow up on the needs and demands for 
semiskilled  and  skilled  labor  in  the  agricultural  value  chain  and  make  market-oriented  training 
accessible to agricultural wage laborers in search for better employment opportunities.  
 
16.  Marketing Competitiveness. Increased production of higher value goods and services 
will increase the volume and value of market transactions. The adoption of various postharvest 
technologies  (including  improved  storage,  packaging,  and  processing  techniques)  will  reduce 

Overall Project Impacts 

 

  

Appendix 12 

53 

postharvest losses, increase quality, provide price stability, and increase competitiveness of the 
producers.  
 
17. 
Poverty  Reduction.  Reducing  the  incidence  of  poverty  in  the  countryside,  where  it  is 
most  prevalent,  will  occur  as  a  result  of  increases  in  income  brought  about  by  growth  in  the 
volume  and  value  of  goods  produced  and  marketed,  and  the  employment  opportunities 
generated.  It  will  occur  to  an  even  greater  extent  as  a  result  of  employment  creation  in  an 
expanded  rural  farm  and  nonfarm  sectors.  Through  its  social  inclusion  activities,  the  Project 
concentrates  its  support  on  socially  and  economically  excluded  groups,  such  as  marginal 
farmers,  the  landless,  dalit  (untouchable  castes),  and  ethnic  minority  population;  and  ensures 
that the benefits and opportunities emerging from commercialization of agriculture will be shared 
equitably  with  them.  Furthermore,  poverty  reduction  impacts  will  extend  beyond  the  simple 
provision  of  a  daily  wage.  Full-time  employment  will  provide  the  possibility  of  sustained 
economic and social betterment. With regular incomes the beneficiaries will be in a position to 
better provide skills and education for their children, helping their families move out of poverty.

Contribution of the sector or subsector to reduce poverty in Nepal: 
Nepal  is  an  agrarian  society  with  agriculture  contributing  40%  of  the  gross  domestic  product.  About  88%  of  the 
population live in rural areas and depend on agriculture for their livelihood. Agriculture is the main source of food and 
income. In the eastern terai, where the holding sizes are the highest at 0.915 hectares (ha) in average, development 
through  agriculture  is  a  promising  option.  Land  use  intensification,  crop  diversification,  and  increased  yield  are 
mechanisms to improve both land and labor productivity. Commercial agriculture is one of the development alternatives 
that presents potential opportunities for economic growth and might reduce vulnerability and poverty. The Agriculture 
Perspective  Plan  considers  agricultural  production  and  the  growth  anticipated  in  employment  opportunities  in 
agriculture and related sectors, such as agrobased industries, as the key to poverty reduction. The plan stresses the 
need to diversify and commercialize agricultural production.  
 
The  Project’s  contribution  to  poverty  reduction  is  expected  in  the  following  areas:  (i)  social  mobilization  and 
organization  of  subsistence  farmers;  landless;  and  vulnerable  such  as  dalit  (untouchable  castes),  low  caste,  ethnic 
groups,  and  women;  (ii)  income  generation  through  high-value  crop  (HVC)  production;  off-season  vegetables;  and 
associated  income  activities  such  as  packaging,  small  processing,  and  marketing  of  produce;  and  (iii)  additional 
employment  opportunities  in  a  more  dynamic  rural  economy.  The  Project  will  address  the  vulnerability  factors  of 
disadvantaged  people  and  enhance  the  capability  of  the  poor  to  engage  directly  in  (or  benefit  indirectly  from) 
commercial agriculture. The Project fosters group formation and will help groups to move to commercial farming, thus 
making  them  eligible  to  become  members  of  the  commercial  agricultural  alliance  (CAA)  and  avail  of  the  commercial 
agricultural fund (CAF). The CAA and CAF will enable all stakeholders to have better access to technology, markets, 
infrastructure, information, and expansion of production and marketing of a broad range of agricultural products.  
 
Group mobilization will motivate subsistence farmers and disadvantaged groups to overcome barriers to organize into 
larger  units,  and  thus  to  better  cope  with  risk;  and  improve  access  to  technology,  markets,  credit,  and  information. 
Group  formation  is  a  strategy  to  cope  with  small  land  size  and  land  fragmentation,  and  to  achieve  critical  mass  for 
commercialization.  In  terms  of  poverty  reduction,  the  socially  inclusive  participation  component  will  provide  positive 
impacts for the poor and vulnerable groups (55% according to surveys conducted during project preparation). 

 

Targeting Classification: General intervention 

B.  Poverty Analysis  
Based  on  the  2001  census,  the  total  population  in  the  11  project  districts  is  4,486,482  (848,107  households), 
comprising  76  recorded  ethnic  groups  in  the  terai  cluster  and  31  groups  in  the  hill/mountain  cluster.  Ethnic  diversity 
needs to be considered when targeting development interventions aimed at livelihood improvement. 
 
An  evaluation  of  the  Ninth  Plan  (1997–2002)  and  the  poverty  situation  clearly  demonstrate  that  past  development 
efforts have fallen behind the expectations of poverty reduction. The main reasons identified were low and unsustained 
broad-based economic growth, inadequate human development, poor accountability, economic malpractices, and poor 
implementation and monitoring of development programs. 
 
In  the  proposed  project  area,  the  reported  main  root  causes  of  poverty  are  lack  of  land  (28.9%),  high  dependency 
rate/illness/disability  (20.1%),  lack  of  awareness  (17.2%),  unemployment  (14.0%),  caste/ethnic  issues  (5.9%),  large 
family  size  (4.2%),  and  economic  situation  (4.2%).  The  poor  and  vulnerable  groups  also  see  the  lack  of  inherited 
assets, caste/ethnic discrimination, and lack of livestock as the main causes of their poverty.  
 
Surveys conducted during project preparation identify four broad socioeconomic groups, based on their level of assets 
and  vulnerability.  Among  them,  55%  are  in  poverty  with  food  unsecured.  About  15%  of  households  identified 
themselves  as  well-off,  mainly  of  Brahmin  and  Newar  origin.  The  main  livelihood  characteristics  were  identified  as 
inherited assets; more than 3 ha of land, property, good education, remittance from foreign employment, pension from 
Britain, income from other business and employment, cardamom cultivator farmers, and food surplus. About 63.6% of 
their  income  comes  from  the  agriculture  sector.  About  30%  of  households  considered  themselves  in  a  medium 
socioeconomic  condition,  comprising  the  Brahmin,  Chhetri,  Lama,  Limbu,  Newar,  Rai,  Sherpa,  and  Tamang  groups. 
The  main  livelihood  characteristics  of  those  households  are  food  sufficiency,  job/pension  holding,  larger  landholding 
(mostly  rain  fed),  permanent  national  and  foreign  employment,  have  cattle  and  cash  crops,  small  business,  and 
education. About 66.4% of their income comes from the agriculture sector. About 30% of households said they were 
poor and lacked food security, education, and permanent paid jobs. They have small landholdings, high dependency 
rate,  weak  financial  capacity,  few  cattle,  and  rely  on  daily  wage  labor  in  Nepal  and  India.  The  highest  share  of

households  in  this  category  comprises  Gurung,  Magar,  Dalit,  and  some  ethnic  groups.  About  63.3%  of  their  income 
comes  from  the  agriculture  sector.  About  25%  of  households  said  they  were  vulnerable  or  very  poor;  most  of  them 
belong to the Dalit and Tharu communities. They are characterized by chronic food deficiency, underemployment, high 
dependency ratio because of illness and disability, low education and literacy rate, lack of inherited assets and land, 
indebtedness,  and  very  low  capital  and  financial  assets.  About  42.9%  of  their  income  comes  from  the  agriculture 
sector. 
 
These two groups, the poor and the vulnerable (comprising 55%), have very little capital, natural, social, and economic 
assets;  and  most  continue  to  adopt  a  survival  strategy  to  secure  food,  basic  needs,  and  shelter  either  through 
subsistence farming or daily wage labor on- and off-farm. Grant assistance from the Japan Fund for Poverty Reduction 
(JFPR)  is  envisaged  with  a  view  to  supplement  the  Project  in  four  districts,  improve  the  livelihood  of  subsistence 
farmers and disadvantaged groups in the agricultural market chain, and provide access to opportunities created by the 
Project.  The  JFPR  assistance  will  (i)  provide  seed  money  and  seed  packages  to  subsistence  farmers  and 
disadvantaged groups in all 11 districts to enable them to participate in the activities and benefit from the Project; (ii) 
support  groups  of  disadvantaged  people  to  get  involved  in  commercial  agriculture;  (iii)  follow  up  on  the  needs  and 
demands for semiskilled and skilled labor in the agricultural value chain, and make market-oriented training accessible 
to agricultural wage laborers in search of better employment opportunities. 
 
C.  Participation Process 
Is there a stakeholder analysis? 
Is there a participation strategy? 
 
The Project was designed based on two approaches, the value chain approach and the participatory learning system 
approach.  The  value-chain  approach  focuses  on  the  interaction  of  participants  in  the  commercial  agriculture  sector, 
and their contribution and interest in adding value in a series of networks. The participatory learning system approach 
is based on the concept of collaborative, experiential learning, and enabled stakeholders to participate in designing and 
validating the project approach. Information was collected from field visits, field work for social analysis, stakeholders’ 
participatory workshops, other stakeholders’ consultations, background reports, district profiles, and regional database. 
 
The  commercial  concept  and  institutional  arrangement  proposed  in  the  Project  are  new  to  Nepal.  The  level  of 
ownership, interest, adoption, and participation of the stakeholders will depend on their common understanding. Given 
the  traditional  social  behavior  and  stratification  of  the  potential  beneficiaries  and  the  relatively  low  level  of  education 
and international references, the understanding of the project objectives and processes is a major challenge to active 
and  sustained  participation  in  building  effective  commercial  value  chains.  Therefore,  the  project  standardization 
workshops  and  awareness  campaign  on  project  values,  objectives,  implementation  procedures,  results,  and  benefits 
will be launched. For subsistence farmers, awareness, self-esteem building, increased labor productivity in wage labor, 
and less discriminatory attitudes and behavior will be part of the mobilization campaign. 
 
D.  Gender Development 
Strategy to maximize impacts on women: 
In  the  project  area,  females  represent  48.5%  of  the  population;  59.1%  are  illiterate  (33.5%  of  males  are  illiterate). 
Women  perform  most  of  the  routine  domestic-related  tasks.  Though  women  and  men  share  activities  in  agricultural 
production, postharvest, and processing, women are generally paid less than men for the same work and for the same 
number  of  hours.  Women  have  lower  access  than  men  to  credit,  information,  and  technology.  Trade  leadership  is 
limited for women. 
 
The  problem  of  gender  imbalance  and  inequity  in  accessing  resources  is  to  be  addressed  by  simultaneously  (i) 
understanding  the  nature  of  intrahousehold  relationships;  (ii)  seeking  economic  opportunities  along  with  commercial 
agriculture activities; (iii) reducing vulnerability and identifying mitigation measures arising from commercial agriculture; 
(iv) enhancing the capability of women to engage directly (or benefit indirectly) in commercial agriculture; (v) integrating 
women  into  effective  value  chains  and  increasing  representation  and  decision  making  of  women  in  commercial 
agriculture; and (vi) increasing representation of women in project structures, CAA, and local government.

Appendix 14 

GENDER ACTION PLAN 

 
1. 
In  the  project  area,  women  represent  48.5%  of  the  population;  59.1%  are  illiterate 
(33.5%  of  males  are  illiterate).  Women  and  men  participate  equally  in  agricultural  production, 
but the participation of women in commercial agriculture is limited. In addition to farm activities, 
women perform  most of the routine domestic tasks. Women are generally paid less than men 
for the same farm or processing work and for the same number of hours. Women have lower 
access  than  men  to  credit,  information,  and  technology.  Commercial  agriculture  development 
needs  to  increase  opportunities  for  women,  not  only  as  unskilled  laborers  but  also  as 
increasingly skilled laborers and more confident decision makers. 
 
2. 
Women’s  Livelihood  Opportunities.  Due  to  the  male-oriented  inheritance  distribution 
system, traditional gender labor allocation in households, and traditional local norms on gender 
access  to  social  services,  women  are  less  prepared  than  men  to  utilize  evolving  economic 
opportunities.  While  men  are  engaged  in  permanent  jobs,  international  and  urban  migration, 
business,  and  trade,  women  tend  to  remain  at  home  to  maintain  house  and  farm,  and  ensure 
children’s  education.  Women  are  usually  not  well  paid  because  they  are  unskilled,  as  a 
consequence  of  their  low  level  of  education.  Without  additional  awareness,  training  programs, 
group  organization,  and  access  to  credit,  improving  the  livelihoods  of  rural  women  will  be 
difficult. 
 
3. 
Conflict-Related Gender Issues. Several districts of the Eastern Development Region 
are affected by violence, insecurity, extortion, and looting of banks. Women’s involvement in the 
Maoist army and political cadres has brought a major break in the social fabric of rural areas. 
Women’s  household  and  farm-related  work  burden  has  increased  dramatically  because  many 
male family members have left the villages. Women must now deal with both security forces and 
Maoists. Brahmin and Chhetri women who were traditionally forbidden to plough fields or repair 
the roofs of houses are taking on these tasks, both out of necessity and because of the evolving 
egalitarian value system. The number of women employed in agriculture, as farm laborers, and 
as  workers  in  agro-industry  decreased  during  the  conflict.  However,  positive  impacts  may  be 
expected  as  the  ban  on  (i)  uncontrolled  production,  sale,  and  public  abuse  of  alcohol;  and  (ii) 
gambling is reportedly being implemented in Maoist-influenced areas. 
 
4. 
Strategy  to  Redress  Gender  Imbalance.  The  problems  of  gender  imbalance  and 
inequity  in  accessing  resources  will  be  addressed  by  simultaneously  (i)  understanding  the 
traditional linear and customary systems that define the nature of intrahousehold relationships; 
(ii)  seeking  economic  opportunities  along  with  commercial  agriculture  activities;  (iii)  reducing 
vulnerability  and  identifying  mitigation  measures  arising  from  commercial  agriculture;  (iv) 
enhancing skills of women to engage directly in or benefit indirectly from commercial agriculture; 
(v)  integrating  women  into  effective  value  chains  and  increasing  representation  of  women  in 
decision-making  in  commercial  agriculture;  and  (vi)  increasing  awareness,  information,  and 
networking. Specific activities for empowering women through project activities are presented in 
Table A14.
